subject: Re: [junit] Enhancement Request: Assert.fail(Exception e) could be useful.
msgSnippet: ... fail(e) does not work and I don t think it should work, because it is longer and harder to read than just letting JUnit catch the exception. Why don t you
messageBody:
On Tuesday 20 January 2004 16:20, Shivanjali Bhutkar wrote:
> trying to understand this one,
> I am also doing same thing. Putting fail(e) should work or is this
> something you are proposing in later realeases? Please confirm..

fail(e) does not work and I don't think it should work, because it is
longer and harder to read than just letting JUnit catch the exception.

Why don't you do it that way?

Robert

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Robert Wenner [mailto:robert@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, January 20, 2004 2:03 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Enhancement Request: Assert.fail(Exception e)
> could be useful.
>
> On Tuesday 20 January 2004 03:54, operationsresearch wrote:
> > The following method could be useful..
> > public static void fail(Exception e)
> > Fails a test with a message containing stack trace of given
> > exception.
>
> How is
>
> public void testWhatever() {
> try {
> // ... some test code ...
> }
> catch (SomeException e) {
> fail(e);
> }
> }
>
> better than just declaring the test to be able to throw
> SomeException?
>
> public void testWhateverThrowing() throws SomeException {
> // ... same test code as from try block above ...
> }
